description: Erection of first floor side extension, single storey rear extension, rear dormer roof extension and installation of rooflights to facilitate loft conversion (Retrospective application)
decision_conditions: The roof of the single storey rear extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the approved drawings, within three months of the date of this consent, the first floor side window in the north-western elevation of the hereby permitted development shall be replaced with a window so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.   Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The ground floor side windows fitted in the north-western elevation of the development hereby approved shall be  fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.   Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the north-western or south-eastern walls of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.16x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 3x representations have been received, which highlight the following concerns:-- The loft extension will violate privacy- Access or traffic problems- Car park issues- Fumes- Noise- PrivacyMatters of impact on amenity are addressed below. Issues regarding to noise could be addressed by condition if needed. There is no reason to conclude that fumes would be an issues, and the development would not materially increase in the size of the dwelling so no issues with regards to car parking would be envisaged. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed rear dormer roof extension, would not be set down from the ridge line of the original roofslope and would not be set in from the sides and eaves of the original roof, contrary to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD. Given the unusual form of the proposed rear dormer roof extension, officers consider the proposal would not be in keeping with the character and appearance of the original dwelling and would appear as an incongruous addition within the immediate surrounding area.  AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the nature of the proposal, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light. There are existing rear first floor windows to habitable rooms at the host property. As a result of these windows, the proposed dormer would not cause increased  overlooking or loss of privacy to neighbouring properties, significant enough to warrant refusal.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Res

The applicant is informed that the submitted details has been assessed by relevant consultants and is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 15 (Construction Environmental Management Plan) of planning permission 21/02865/PAMA which states:Before the development hereby approved commences, a Construction Environmental Management Plan (CEMP) shall be submitted to, and approved in writing by, the Local Planning Authority. The CEMP shall comprise measures for controlling the effects of demolition, construction and enabling works associated with the development as may be approved by the Local Planning Authority. The CEMP shall address issues including the phasing of the works, air quality, noise, waste management, site remediation, plant and equipment, site transportation and traffic management including routing, signage, permitted hours for construction traffic and construction materials deliveries. It will ensure appropriate communication with, the distribution of information to the local community and the Local Planning Authority relating to relevant aspects of construction. Appropriate arrangements should be made for monitoring and responding to complaints relating to demolition and construction. All demolition, construction and enabling work at the development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved CEMP unless otherwise agreed in writing by the LPA.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase in order to protect air quality, safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with Policies CS7 and DM9, DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012 and Policy SI 1 of the London Plan and the GLA SPG Control of Dust and Emissions During Construction.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details has been assessed by relevant consultants and is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Conditions 7 (Acoustic Report) and 8 (Odour Management Plan) of planning permission 21/03194/FUL, which states: Conditions 7 (Acoustic Report) -Before the use hereby permitted commences, an acoustic report shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority demonstrating that the rating level of any plant, permitted as part of this development, will be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation.  The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade.  Measurements and assessment shall be made according to British Standard 4142:2014.Condition 8 (Odour Management Plan) -No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied, or the use commenced, until there has been submitted to and approved in writing, by the Local Planning Authority, an Odour Management Plan, setting out cleaning, maintenance and filter replacement policies. The plan should include a written recording system to record and demonstrate when all such work is carried out. The approved odour management plan shall be complied with throughout the duration of the use. Reason: To safeguard the amenity of nearby premises, residential properties and the wider area.
